body: This will allow us to do more interesting things with memory allocation within toxcore, and allow fuzzers to explore various allocation failure paths. - - - This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/TokTok/c-toxcore/2393)

comment_data.body: This should probably be removed or uncommented?
What does it mean to have supported types here?
Have you run this under a fuzzer, or just drive-by fixes?

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,86 @@
+/* SPDX-License-Identifier: GPL-3.0-or-later
+ * Copyright © 2016-2018 The TokTok team.
+ * Copyright © 2013 Tox project.
+ */
+
+/**
+ * Datatypes, functions and includes for the core networking.

comment_data.body: All of these have `obj` marked as non_null(), but when using the system memory, `obj` will always be null?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,88 @@
+/* SPDX-License-Identifier: GPL-3.0-or-later
+ * Copyright © 2016-2018 The TokTok team.
+ * Copyright © 2013 Tox project.
+ */
+
+#include "mem.h"
+
+#include <stdlib.h>
+
+#include "ccompat.h"
+
+non_null()
+static void *sys_malloc(void *obj, uint32_t size)

comment_data.body: I guess these should have some form of documentation if they live in tox.h?
Should this assert(tox != nullptr) like we do in the other functions taking a `Tox *`?
It requires a newer version of the fuzz rules, but our msan image is still broken, so until then I can't uncomment it. Should I remove it?
Cimple will error on unsupported ones. I figured I'd document it so people know, rather than wait for cimple to complain at them.
Static analysis told me about it. I don't remember which one.

comment_data.body: Actually, deleted. The next PR does this differently.
Leaving it is fine, I just didn't know the context of the change.

A bit confused by this PR and #2397 both introducing the mem module and using new system_{random,network,memory}. Is one PR build on top of another? Or perhaps these are alternative implementations of the same thing?
@nurupo this one introduces the mem, #2397 should just be moving stuff around (afaik)

commit.message:
refactor: Add `mem` module to allow tests to override allocators.

This will allow us to do more interesting things with memory allocation
within toxcore, and allow fuzzers to explore various allocation failure
paths.
